head.title: Public Ownership Is Good Public Relations

hedline.hl1: Public Ownership Is Good Public Relations

block.p: LEAD: Sometimes public leaders lose touch with reality as they sit at their lonely pinnacle of power. Some never had much of a grasp to start with. Richard Kessel, chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, is an example.

LEAD: Sometimes public leaders lose touch with reality as they sit at their lonely pinnacle of power. Some never had much of a grasp to start with. Richard Kessel, chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, is an example.

Sometimes public leaders lose touch with reality as they sit at their lonely pinnacle of power. Some never had much of a grasp to start with. Richard Kessel, chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, is an example.
In his Long Island Opinion article, he tries to share his prejudice against Lilco and his fantasy of an electricity-starved but nuclear free Long Island.

Mr. Kessel seems to dwell on Lilco's ability to reward their executives, yet fails to observe his own string of rewards for his anti-establishment behavior at the hands of his personal benefactor and ideological twin, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Kessel and Govenor Cuomo also seem to confuse Lilco with a spiritual entity, for they hold Lilco personally responsible for Hurricane Gloria and its resultant problems.

However, with all their faults, and there are more than a few, at least Lilco delivers a product and a service. If it were not for Messrs. Kessel, Cuomo and their ilk, we on Long Island would have adequate electricity this year. Instead we will probably experience ever more outages and brownouts, while L.I.P.A. will exhort all of us to use less electricity, or to use it when we should be sleeping. No doubt L.I.P.A. will issue a plethora of reports and hot air, the sum of which will have no more practical use than to drive a child's pinwheel or start charcoal for a barbecue.

As we swelter and suffer, let us remember that it is we, Lilco's ratepayers, who will pay the billions of dollars that the Shoreham plant costs, and the interest on that debt. And if you have the stamina, you can ponder where the money will come from to dismantle the Shoreham plant, and to convert Shoreham or build another facility to generate more electricity.

Justice would be served if we could pass the bill on to Messrs. Kessel/Cuomo. But since their pockets are not deep enough, the honor will fall to all of us. And some will pay happily, knowing that we have dismantled a safe, clean and environmentally benign electricity generating plant, and have exchanged it for a huge debt and carbon dioxide generating plants burning fossil fuels that will become ever more expensive.
